header.title: ‘Racist’ patient slammed by hospital bosses after demanding to be seen by white doctor
header.postText: A patient who demanded to be seen by a ‘white doctor’ has been branded ‘appalling’.', 'Hospital boss Andrew Foster, and CEO of Wrightington, Wigan and Leigh NHS Foundation Trust, described the incident as ‘deeply upsetting’ for all of the staff.', 'Sharing the details on Twitter, he said: ‘Would you believe a patient coming to A&E and asking to see a white doctor?', '‘When politely told that a white doctor was not available, the patient walked out and has formally complained about this. This was hugely upsetting for the staff involved. Appalling.’', 'Speaking to Manchester Evening News, Mr Foster said that it wasn’t ‘unusual’ to report something like that: ‘Sadly we’ve spoken to consultants in A&E and they agree. It happens from time to time, usually when somebody has been drinking too much.', '‘What is most unusual in this case, is that the patient has issued a complaint against us. That, to my knowledge, is unique.’', 'It is understood that the patient was in the A&E department, when a young doctor went to do an initial assessment.', 'The patient told the doctor at the outset that he did not want to see him, but wanted to ‘see a white doctor’.', 'The medical professional left the cubicle and contacted his consultant who was also non-white.', 'Mr Foster said: ‘The consultant calmly explained that that isn’t the way it works – you have to see the next available doctor. The patients said ‘well I’m off’, and then left. There was no violence or shouting, it was a simple request.’', 'It’s said that the junior doctor had not received such overt racism before, and was left ‘very, very upset’ following the altercation.', 'The patient has not been publicly identified, but Mr Foster confirmed that they had been banned from Wigan Infirmary, and it had been passed on to Greater Manchester Police.

commentThread.commentText: Whilst I detest racism, by the sounds of what happened as reported, the patient made a request and then left after it was explained to him how the system works. I fail to see why it would need to be reported to the police on that merit alone, regardless of a formal complaint being made. It seems strange we would treat a person as a criminal for asking a question as deluded as that question might be, if he doesn't want to be treated then he is the one missing out on what otherwise would be a professional and competent service provided by the NHS. It's his own loss.A person is entitled to be racist and hold views contrary to what the rest of us think, so long as they don't behave in a way which is either violent or abusive to another. I don't see why there would be any need to publicly shame anyone either, akin to a point of organised outrage based on presumptions as bad as the racists own views, such a person would make a rod their own back and be quite plainly exposed by their daily activities without the metaphorical tar and feathering.If people are to change their views it needs to be done in ways which doesn't entrench them deeper in hatred.. especially when they ask a question.Whatever complaint the person made however needs to be met appropriately regardless of the bigot making it. We don't or shouldn't have tiers of justice depending on attitude. But certainly, throw out that which is vexatious.

replies.commentText: Except for the fact that cretinous time wasters like this use valuable resources at the expense of others. It is also illegal to discriminate against someone because of their race. This includes the workplace.

He left quietly yes, but then made a formal complaint against the A&E for not being seen by a white doctor - that is abusive and a hate crime - which is against the law. This is the difference to your typical A&E racist.

commentThread.commentText: While it may seem racist we don’t know the background of the person - they could have mental issues, may have been abused by non-white people etc...or he just may be more comfortable around white people. Instead what has happened this patient that needed medical help was refused because he wanted to be seen by a white doctor. Had he been seen by a non-white doctor this could have caused the patient stress and worsen his problem. Yes his request was arguabl y racist BUT what harm would it have done to say “well we can try but we can’t make any promises and it may be a longer wait”. Had he kicked off, shouted abuse, called people racists names - then refuse to see him...although even then t he doctors etc have taken an oath to help all people etc. This situation could have been handled in a far better way. What about when women request to see a female doctor for certain things - isn’t t hat sexism?What about when certain religious people request cer tain doctors etc. Racism exist in the world but that’s not a reason to treat a patient - treat the patient and deal wi th the racism afterwards.
